annotation.TEXT: Axe Man can be kind of tricky until you nail down his pattern: He'll jump either 2 or 3 times before attacking (each time he lands, he'll shake the ground - which actually damages you). For his first pattern, he'll throw 2 axes in an arcing path, and then swing a single axe that produces three projectiles. After that, he'll invert his pattern (two axe swings followed by an arcing axe).

Also making an appearance in this game are the collectible letters. There's one in each of the 8 main stages, and getting all of them will unlock a particular animal buddy (one that received a dynamic upgrade when compared to how he works in the official games).

Notice how he goes back and forth between the attack patterns? Additionally, he always starts off with the 2 arcing axes followed by an axe swing. If you keep in mind which pattern he'll use next, this fight becomes much easier to deal with.

Leaf Man is relatively simple to deal with in terms of patterns, seeing as he repeats the same motions over and over again. The thing you need to keep in mind for this fight is positioning yourself well to avoid his attacks. There's actually quite a few ways you can go about avoiding his leaf boomerangs, so there's a strong possibility the way I handle this isn't even the most efficient way to do this fight (the method seen here is just the one I feel most comfortable using).

Much like everyone else who has played this, I find "Citrus Quack" here to be the funniest looking mid-boss ever. During a Twitch stream of this game, Mr. Weird Guy revealed that Citrus Quack is actually based on a random character he drew on his friend's windshield at one point (which at the time was known as the "Lemon Duck Flower").

Leaf Boomerang is great as both a weapon and supporting utility. Aside from hitting multiple times, the leaves actually linger inside an enemy once it hits them (thus causing even more damage). It can also pick up and bring back almost any item that happens to be laying around (the only things it can't retrieve are E-Tanks and the collectible letters).

Soak Man is another boss that can potentially cause some problems until you nail down the gist of his pattern: He'll fire a slow moving bubble that bounces around the room, jump, fire off 3 bubbles straight forward, jump twice, then use his Soak Rain attack. Repeat. The last part can easily be avoided by jumping over him. If you have the Zap Barrier though...you can pretty much toss any semblance of strategy out the window and just run into him.

The path to the left actually leads to a small area with a bunch of bolts. I'm not going out of my way to get them however since I don't plan on buying anything in the shop - or at least, any of the major upgrade items. The reason for this is that you actually unlock something at the end of the game if you finish it without any upgrades on-hand (while vice-versa, you also get something else if you beat the game with every upgrade in your possession).

From what I've seen, apparently a lot of people like to go to Wizard Man first (seeing as he gives you Rush Jet). Honestly though, the routing for this game in a casual playthrough is really flexible. Any order is good because every weapon is good - and I do mean really, really good. This game is a pretty strong contender for having one of the best weapon-sets out there.

Mega Man SFR has come a long way since the demo that was released back in April. With the release of the full game, I can't exactly pass up the opportunity to a playthrough on it, especially given how much of it has changed.

Zap Barrier is still one of the best weapons in the game. Using it makes Mega Man completely invincible for a few moments, and it damages any enemy you run into (the only things that can kill you while it's active are bottomless pits and a certain hazard in Coal Man's stage). The only real donwside is that it has more limited uses when compared to the other weapons (7 uses in total).

On that note, I will be showing everything else you can unlock once this main run of the game is finished (most likely through a bonus segment which will outline the proceedures for unlocking everything).

As mentioned by several others at this point, Soak Rain is basically what Thunder Wool should have been. It fires out three clouds in an upwards arc (similar to the path of the Air Shooter, but it doesn't travel as quickly) to dispense rain over a large area. Its damage output is pretty good, and it has an alternate function of putting out fires in one particular stage.

Zap Man has been toned down a bit since the demo. Aside from not doing as much damage, he's also a bit slower than before, making his attacks a bit easier to avoid. Beyond that, his pattern is essentially the same as it always was.

Now then, time for the basic run-down: Mega Man still controls like he did from MM4 to 8 (chargable buster, slide, etc), but there are a few minor differences which are actually pretty helpful. For one, getting hit won't reset any charged shots you've been building up. Additionally, you more or less have an infinite slide in this game. Just hold down and mash the jump button to continue your slide (the timing on it is pretty lenient, so it's very easy to execute).

In the demo, these swinging axes used to drain you to a single point of health. Thankfully, this is no longer the case. Getting hit by them will take off half of your current life (which can still hurt a ton, but it's way better than being instantly put into Owata-mode).

Giant Axe is this game's go-to shield piercing weapon. It deals strong damage on contact, and it can land multiple hits depending on how you catch enemies in its arc. You can also change the axe's arc by holding up or down.

These spikes that jut out of the ground when you pass over them aren't instant death. Rather, they're actually a 2 hit kill (they deal 14 damage on Normal Mode, 17 damage on Hard Mode, and 21 damage on the hidden difficulty mode).

For those of you wondering where the next Plague Knight segment is, feel free to read the description for some more info on what's going on with that series. For now, it's finally time to get started with this game.
Yes, the Moles from Metal Man's stage return in this game, but thankfully they're way easier to deal with here (they only emerge in set areas, rather than just randomly spawning everywhere).
